measured_by: 9-point moral acceptability rating scale (1 = completely unacceptable, 9 = completely acceptable)
justification: “Moral acceptability ratings. To determine the extent to which the action by the agent is morally acceptable, participants provided moral acceptability ratings between 1 (completely unacceptable) and 9 (completely acceptable).”

“Confusion. To assess for confusion, participants indicated whether they were: not confused, confused at first but understood the material enough by the end, or confused enough to believe their answers to the questions were not reasonable.”

“Realism. To assess whether participants believed the dilemmas were realistic, participants indicated whether they found the dilemmas: to be realistic, did not find it realistic but responded under the assumption that it was accurate, or did not find it realistic which resulted in inability to take the description seriously.”

The paper states that trolley-type moral dilemmas are “a simple and ethical way to determine when one would elicit a consequentialist or deontological response,” and the study “is a direct replication of experiments 1a and 1b of Greene et al. (2009)” using the footbridge and speedboat dilemmas.
